results.title: Chemistry for sixth forms: catalysis
results.creator_credit: Donald Carter, Associated Television and Phil Wrestler
results.brief_description: The term “catalysis” and its importance in industrial processes; homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis; catalytic cracking of petroleum; Faraday’s theory on the cause of surface catalysis; Sabatier-Senderens process using nickel as a catalyst in hydrogenation of vegetable oils; effect of poisons on surface catalysis; effect of manganese dioxide on hydrogen peroxide.

results.title: Chemistry and a changing world
results.brief_description: This film directs the student’s attention to the significance of chemistry in the modern world. It traces the steps leading up to the reproduction of electric furnace phosphorus. In showing the work of research chemists and chemical engineers who work from an original idea until it reaches its final form in the shape of a finished product, the film also provides information which may be of value in vocational guidance.

results.title: Chemicals in the Workplace
results.creator_credit: Kim Dalton and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: An informative program which lists harmful chemicals that are commonly used in industry. The dangerous effects that these chemicals may have on the human body, if not properly protected, are discussed and workers who have suffered from the adverse effects, of the chemicals, talk about their injuries.

results.title: Chemical reactions II
results.creator_credit: Barrie Whatley, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Demonstrates a series of chemical reactions designed to show that the course of the reaction can be followed by measuring various parameters. One reaction shown is that between tertiary butyl bromide and water, and rates are observed by measuring the volume of a gas evolved, the ph change, change of boiling point, and changes in light absorption during reactions.

results.title: Chemical reactions I
results.creator_credit: Barrie Whatley, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Discusses the vibration and dissociation of a diatomic molecule. From these simple systems the theoretical ideas that are used to discuss the role of energy in chemical reactions are developed.

results.title: Chemical properties of water
results.brief_description: An explanation of the chemical properties of water in terms of the polar nature of the water molecule. Demonstrates chemical reactions of water with metals, metal oxides, non-metal oxides, and salts; shows how water, as a solvent, promotes other chemical reactions.

results.title: Chemical families
results.creator_credit: David W. Ridgway, J. Arthur Campbell and Davidson Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Starting with a display of samples of over 70 elements, the film demonstrates methods by which chemical similarities among the elements have provided the basis for dividing them logically into families. By experiment and observation metals, non-metals, and the doubtful elements are grouped. The film demonstrates how atomic numbers have provided the key to the ordering of the elements in the periodic table.

results.title: Chemical evolution
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Origin of Life”.
Evidence supporting evolution of life in the primordial sea is the basis for the film’s content. Actual footage of scientific investigations is featured. These include: Russian biochemist - AI Oparin; Dr Stanley Miller and Dr Cyril Ponnamperuma. We also see a miniature amino acid analyser and other complex analytical apparatus at NASA’s Ames Research Centre.

results.title: Chemical equilibrium
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: chemistry”.
These episodes examine the theory of steady state, dynamic equilibrium, kinetic molecular theory, reaction tendencies and the equilibrium constant. Illustrates forward and reverse reactions of various chemical changes including the production of hydrogen iodide, hydrogen chloride and ammonia. Finally, through demonstrations of Le Chatlier’s principle and the Haber process, students gain a better understanding of the importance of chemical equilibrium. The episodes are “Unsteady steadiness”, “Dynamic equilibrium”, Reaction kinetics”, “The Equilibrium constant” mand “The Haber process
